Title: Image builder refactor 23042018
Body: # Most refactor of image_builder tool  **Include:**   * Publish message to GH with `curl`   * Change type of config-file from `ini` format to `JSON`   * Use v2.0.0 [GWBT Jenkins plugin](https://github.com/urpylka/jenkins-github-webhook-build-trigger-plugin/tree/body_as_json) @urpylka   * Fix many bugs    More info about hardware configure there https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/issues/38.

Title: image_buider enable hardware uart with raspi config
Body: Now  in image doesn't work hardware UART. About this problem there https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/issues/41.    After replace https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/commit/0346c48546590faa00f7ee0a1d0ea71f6343bd17 our [forked scripts](  https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/blob/v0.4/image_builder/scripts/hardware_setup.sh) to `raspi-config`  I can't turn on only HW interface wo user console on this version of `raspi-config`. But I found solution there https://github.com/RPi-Distro/raspi-config/pull/75.    **Next  after adding this commit https://github.com/RPi-Distro/raspi-config/commit/d6d9ecc0d9cbe4aaa9744ae733b9cb239e79c116 to official Raspbian OS release we can use**:  ```(bash)  /usr/bin/raspi-config nonint do_serial 2  ```    More information you can find there https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/issues/38

Title: image_builder use dnsmasq as default dhcp server

And now I made hack to replace `dtparam` to stopper script.  P.S. After next session `PATH` is become normal. And script self-removed.    Any ideas?    More information you can find there https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/issues/38

Title: New structure of the CLEVER
Body: Some features:    * Use Docker ([img-tool](https://github.com/urpylka/img-tool)) for build images on any x86 platforms  * Use Debian packages for all ROS dependencies ([repo.coex.space](http://repo.coex.space))  * Use Travis instead Jenkins

Title: Build script fixes
Body: Right now the build system attempts to upgrade pip system-wide. This fails for several reasons:     * ```pip3``` seems to no longer exist in [PyPI](https://pypi.org/search/?q=pip3)     * Debian uses an unsupported API for pip (https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/5240  https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/5221)     * Upgrading pip system-wide through pip itself is generally frowned upon (https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/5599)  it's a task for the system package manager     * Not entirely related  but ```pip``` now refers to ```pip3``` by default    This PR disables upgrading pip system-wide. End users should be able to upgrade pip in their virtual environments and/or on a per user basis.

Title: build Kill dirmngr before unmounting chroot
Body: ```dirmngr``` is preventing us from unmounting the image properly. It should not be running in a chrooted environment  especially after the script exits from one  but our interactions with ```systemctl``` might start it as a service.    This P/R attempts to stop ```dirmngr``` service so that the image could be unmounted cleanly.    I don't expect this to fix all builds  there might be other issues elsewhere.

Title: build Update python rosdep to 0 14 0
Body: python-rosdep 0.13.0 was removed from Raspbian repositories  breaking our build.    [Changelog](https://github.com/ros-infrastructure/rosdep/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst) seems innocent enough  should be a trivial fix. Using a more recent rosdep should have an added benefit of ignoring ROS distros that we don't care about.

Title: ros Add compressed_image_transport installation
Body: Install compressed_image_transport by default. The packages are present in the repository.

Title: Automatically build and lint documentation
Body: Disabled automatic deployments for now  though.    Fixed some issues found in the docs along the way.

Title: Use official Raspbian mirror cache downloaded image
Body: Some of our builds have failed because initial Raspbian image download took too long. Curiously enough  downloading from the official mirror sometimes fails as well  but should probably be a little more stable.    Still  we could also use Travis cache  since our base image tends to not change as often. This P/R does this as well.

Title: ROS Use ROS_HOSTNAME instead of ROS_IP
Body: This should allow us to access Clever nodes by hostname as well as its IP address. This may have an added benefit of working over different network configurations.

Title: selfcheck Check logs for errors
Body: Добавлена довольно топорная проверка  запущены ли сервисы и что в логах.

Title: selfcheck Perform version and preflight checks
Body: Добавил проверки версии и вывода `commander check`. Обе проверки не очень надёжные  потому что формат вывода команд от версии к версии может меняться.    Side note: если сразу после создания Publisher'а пытаться что-то публиковать в топик  ничего не опубликуется (поэтому перед публикацией делается довольно тупой `rospy.sleep`). Вполне возможно  что я просто что-то делаю не так.

Title: Fast docs rebuild for pull requests
Body: Some pull requests contain changes for our documentation only. These pull requests may and should be processed quickly: the build should only fail for them if they don't pass linting.    This pull request disables building the whole image for pull requests that only contain changes for docs. This should result in a better user experience for documentation contributors  cutting the response time from our CI from an hour to a couple of minutes.

Title: clever Move udev rule file add note to readme
Body: This P/R moves `99-px4fmu.rules` from builder to the Clever package and adds it to install lists (when building Clever as a debian package). It also includes a note about installing the rules manually.    Note that the device name for the flight controller connected over USB is still `/dev/px4fmu`  this is to avoid confusion with USB-UART adapters renamed to `/dev/ttyPixhawk`.

Title: Add workaround for avahi not working on loopback interfaces
Body: As of now  avahi doesn't work with loopback interfaces. This results in Clever ROS nodes being unable to communicate with ROS master  even though they are all running locally.    This adds a workaround for this problem  placing a record for <hostname>.local in /etc/hosts. This does not sound like a good solution (a better one would be to make Clever resolvable by its hostname on every network  but so far I couldn't find a way to do that reliably).

Title: Rework assigning hostname and service files
Body: * Refuse using `roscore.env` as this is kind of a hack. Instead  source `setup.bash` from .service files.  * Set `ROS_HOSTNAME` equal to `<hostname>.local` in .service-files.  * Add `<hostname>.local` to `hosts`-file to make ROS work with all interfaces down (solution from https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/pull/137).  * Add an instruction on how to rename the machine.  * Add `--skip-log-check` to `clever.service` as the log directory is already get checked in `roscore.service`.  * Remove requiring `roscore.service` from `clever.service` as `--wait` key already makes roslaunch wait for roscore.

Title: builder Add nanorc for launch files
Rework gitbook add Clever 4 instruction
Body: **Rendered version**: http://chev.me/cl4wip/ru/index.html.    * Rework the structure.  * Add Clever 4 assembling instruction.  * Rework setup articles.  * Many additional changes.

Title: ROS Melodic compatibility for aruco_pose package
Body: ROS Melodic dropped the OpenCV package and relies on the system package version. For supported systems this translates to OpenCV 3.2.0  which has API incompatibilities in aruco package.    This P/R introduces checks for OpenCV version and reroutes API access to match currently used OpenCV.

Title: Move to Raspbian Buster
Body: Raspbian Buster is the next version of Raspbian. It brings major updates to many packages and is the first Raspbian version to support Raspberry Pi 4.    We need to rebuild our packages against it  make sure everything works as before and roll it out in one of our subsequent releases.    For now  the list of things to be done is as follows:    - [x] Make sure our base packages are built against Buster  - [x] Have a build that gets to our tests  - [x] Have a build that passes our tests  - [ ] Perform basic performance tests    Some "nice to have" things:    - [x] Build against ROS Melodic  - [ ] Build against ROS Melodic with Python 3    Issues with the build:    - [x] Lots of spurious `object cannot be preloaded` errors **Workaround: move `/etc/ld.so.preload` during the build**  - [x] Monkey does not create `/etc/monkey/sites/default` by default **The Debian version is far too old  so we use the one from our repo**

Title: Limit syslog size
Body: Note: `rsyslog` is not very well documented and these changes may very well be incorrect. I could not replicate the `-` option for files (according to [a Server Fault answer](https://serverfault.com/questions/223148/does-the-sign-have-meaning-in-rsyslog-conf)  it turns off syncing after logging - this is [referenced in the manual](https://www.rsyslog.com/doc/v8-stable/configuration/actions.html)  but is very hard to find even if you know it's there). This may result in lots of writes and  eventually  a dead SD card.    Another thing I could not manage to do is automatic log rotation - `logrotate` invocation does not work for some reason (`rm` does  so it's not exactly an issue with `rsyslog`).

Title: Enable ROS services after first boot
Body: ROS services are enabled on first boot. These services serve no purpose when the system is not configured  but still require time to start and stop. This P/R moves enabling these services to the init_rpi.sh script.

Title: Add LED strip support layer
Body: * Install `led_msgs` package and ws281x driver as `clever` dependencies.  * Set the `setuid` bit to ws281x driver node for running without root permissions.  * Add `led` node  allowing user to control LED strip with effects and program reactions to flight events using ROS params.  * Add default launch-file for LED related stuff  include it to `clever.launch`.  * Add basic test (running the `led` node without failures).

Title: Move to Raspbian Buster
Body: (replacing #156 - third time's the charm?)    Raspbian Buster is the next version of Raspbian. It brings major updates to many packages and is the first Raspbian version to support Raspberry Pi 4.    We need to rebuild our packages against it  make sure everything works as before and roll it out in one of our subsequent releases.    For now  the list of things to be done is as follows:    - [x] Make sure our base packages are built against Buster  - [x] Have a build that gets to our tests  - [x] Have a build that passes our tests  - [ ] Perform basic performance tests    - No major regressions reported so far  - [x] Change the docs to reflect transition to Melodic    Some "nice to have" things:    - [x] Build against ROS Melodic  - [x] Build against ROS Melodic with Python 3 (in branch [`buster`](https://github.com/CopterExpress/clever/tree/buster-py3))    Issues with the build:    - [x] Lots of spurious `object cannot be preloaded` errors **Workaround: move `/etc/ld.so.preload` during the build**  - [x] Monkey does not create `/etc/monkey/sites/default` by default **The Debian version is far too old  so we use the one from our repo**

Title: Add Avahi services broadcasting
Body: Right now we use Avahi for hostname resolution. This allows us to not worry about DNS misconfigurations and provides name resolution on all interfaces. However  since Avahi does not actually advertise any services on the network  device discovery on the network is still somewhat complicated - you either have to know the hostname beforehand or scan the network using `nmap`. We can do better.    I propose leveraging the Avahi service discovery feature to allow simple drone enumeration on the network without requiring access to a router or performing an `nmap`. The service description files are copied to `/etc/avahi/services` and contain service descriptions  ports  and [other service metadata](https://www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/5-avahi.service/).    A host broadcasting its services will be detectable by command-line and GUI applications that enumerate these services (like `avahi-browse` and `avahi-discover` on Ubuntu Linux  `dns-sd` and [Discovery](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/discovery-dns-sd-browser/id1381004916?mt=12) on macOS)  as well as other apps that search for a specific exposed service over the network.    ### Sample output from `avahi-browse -a`    ```  $ avahi-browse -a  + wlp0s20f3 IPv6 Web interface for clover-6943                 Web Site             local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv4 Web interface for clever-9167                 Web Site             local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv4 Web interface for clover-6943                 Web Site             local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv6 SSH on clever-9167                            SSH Remote Terminal  local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv6 SSH on clover-6943                            SSH Remote Terminal  local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv6 clover-6943                                   SSH Remote Terminal  local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv4 SSH on clever-9167                            SSH Remote Terminal  local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv4 SSH on clover-6943                            SSH Remote Terminal  local  + wlp0s20f3 IPv4 clover-6943                                   SSH Remote Terminal  local  ```    ### Sample output from `avahi-discover`    ![Screenshot from 2020-05-18 14-13-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7681612/82207009-d8433b80-9911-11ea-90ef-16d527c326d4.png)

Title: docs Add PDF generation
Body: It appears that there is some demand for PDFs with our documentation. This P/R adds PDF generation into our CI pipeline.

Title: My changes to simulator config
Body: Proposed changes:    1\. Remove all the PX4 copy-paste stuff.    I insist it’s a very bad idea  and I don't want to have this solution as the "official" Clover simulator. In my version you just clone PX4 in a separate workspace (`px4_ws` in my case) and build it isolated adding its `setup.bash` to `.bashrc`. Then PX4 binary just runs as a ROS-node and everything works ok.    This solution is way more clear. If you say that’s to be to difficult for the user  well  that’s plenty ways to simplify it: pre-configured VM images  Docker images  Debian packages.    If  for some reason  we need to have changes in PX4 firmware  we can commit them to our fork. If we need a startup script for the simulator we commit it like this: https://github.com/CopterExpress/Firmware/commit/ffd647ad0464bd49febf22f6e5a3226e8f5c9b44 (again  WITHOUT copy-paste).    2\. Remove unnecessary comments.  There is absolutely no reason to be SO verbose in comments:    ```xml  <!-- Main camera -->  <arg name="main_camera" default="true"/>  ```    I’m not blind  I see that’s main camera! No reason to tell it twice!    3\. `simulated` renamed to `simulator`. Let’s be simpler.

Title: Fix XML formatting in generated world when adding ArUco markers
Body: Changed the way of adding an XML element into the .world file to fix the formatting issue.    This is the most optimal way to add proper indentation and new lines. By default  when editing an XML document this way  the xml.etree.ElementTree module wouldn't add a new line after an inserted element.     There is another way to build a new XML document. It requires the lxml.etree module. This way you can discard all the original document formatting (whitespaces  line breaks) by parsing it with a custom parser (e.g. parser = etree.XMLParser(remove_blank_text=True)) and build a brand new pretty formatted document by using the write() function with the pretty_print=True argument.  But the downside of this approach is that you lose all the empty lines that separated blocks in the original XML document. Not only this approach requires more change  it also requires the manual recreation of those blank lines which is too much work for such simple task as adding an element to an XML document.

Title: Python 3 transition
Body: (I am not comfortable even opening this P/R  but I guess we should do this eventually)    As of 2020  Python 2 is no longer maintained. Package registries are working for now  but new software should use Python 3 instead.  This is concerning for us  since Clever (Clover?) is an educational platform  and teaching how to use deprecated tools is not our goal. As such  we are transitioning to Python 3.    This transition is somewhat complicated:  * ROS Melodic still uses Python 2;  * ROS Noetic is not out yet (and will probably only be ready by summer);  * not all packages support Python 3.    I've done some preparations for Python 3 (for example  I've built our dependencies against it  patching as required). There are still some issues to be resolved  though:  - [x] ~~Butterfly should be running from a virtual environment (may be resolved by patching `rosbridge_suite`)~~ (UPDATE: May be worked around by using an older `tornado` version) Butterfly runs like before  it just uses an older Tornado version;  - [ ] `rosbridge_suite` does not work with Python 3 (UPDATE: Should be fixed by https://github.com/RobotWebTools/rosbridge_suite/pull/460) (UPDATE 2: We are using a patched build that should work);  - [x] `cv_bridge` seems to work after applying these patches: https://github.com/ros-perception/vision_opencv/pull/312;  - [x] ~~`python-opencv` is not getting installed (since it's not required anywhere)~~ `python-opencv` is installed explicitly;  - [x] ~~native tests are failing because of `#!/usr/bin/env python3` shebangs~~ All tests now use `ros_pytest`  which selects the correct interpreter automatically;  - [ ] documentation needs to be updated (mainly the usage of `print` statements in Python)    This is still a work-in-progress  but we should perform regular builds from this branch and try using them. This needs to be thoroughly tested before merge.

Title: Noetic transition with Python 3 and 64 bit Raspberry Pi OS
Body: This P/R addresses the need to transition to the latest ROS release  along with the much-requested Python 3 support (see also: #215  #154). The main difference here is that this is no longer a "hacked together ROS-like distribution"  ROS Noetic supports Python 3 natively.    Another big change here is the operating system  which is finally a 64-bit one. It is still based on Debian Buster  so there shouldn't be major changes in terms of usability. Still  since Buster is officially supported as a ROS Noetic target platform  and as such has prebuilt packages for it (at least for arm64)  the Clover image now benefits from upstream packages. End users will no longer have to struggle compiling their own packages that are missing from the COEX repo.    OpenCV is updated as well  the image now uses the 4.2.0 packages from the COEX repo. Since this is not what comes in Buster by default  several ROS packages still had to be recompiled; these packages are installed from the COEX repo  and will not be updated automatically.    P/R progress:    * [x] Noetic native build target;  * [x] Raspberry Pi image build;  * [x] "Smoke tests" (the resulting image boots  LED strip works  rangefinder works  camera works);  * [ ] Flight tests (cannot be performed by me);  * [ ] Simulation plugins (they do compile  but I haven't done extensive tests);  * [ ] Documentation

Title: image utilize camera info manager
Body: This PR switches to using [camera info manager](http://wiki.ros.org/camera_info_manager) style for storing the main camera calibration.    This is more correct way for managing camera calibrations. Calibrations stored in `.ros/camera_info` directory  and the correct calibration file is selected using the camera name.    Thus  calibration may now be (permanently) changed via `set_camera_info` service. This is utilized by ROS [camera calibration package](http://wiki.ros.org/camera_calibration)  so *COMMIT* button can save the resulting calibration. Also it can be used by out web camera calibration tool.
